bib_record.title: Charge distribution studies in the odd-Z fissioning systems

free_txt: Radiochemistry Division, Bhabha Atomic
Research Centre, Trombay, Mumbai 400 085, India
Research reactors CIRUS and APSARA of
Bhabha Atomic Research Centre, Trombay, Mumbai
The photo peak of the gamma lines of the
fission products were calculated from their total
peak area by the standard program provided in the PC
card.
From the photo peak areas, the cumulative yields of
fission products relative to  some internal fission
product monitors were determined using decay the
equations.On the other hand the independent yields [IY]
were determined using standard decay-growth equations
after correcting for the precursor contribution.
The gamma lines and the nuclear spectroscopic data
of different nuclides were taken from:
* E. Browne, R.B. Firestone, in: V.S. Shirley (Ed.),
Tables of Radioactive Isotopes, 1986.
* J.Blachot,Ch.Fiche, Ann.Phys.(Paris)6,3-218(1981).
The aluminum or Lexan catcher or the
radiochemically separated sample solutions were
counted on a 120 cm*3 HPGe detector coupled to a PC
based 4 K channel analyzer to determine the gamma-
ray activities of various fission products. The
resolution of the detector system was 1.8 keV at
1332.0 keV. The dead time was always kept less than
10% by maintaining appropriate distance between
sample and detector to avoid pile up effect.
The quoted uncertainty on the independent
isomeric yield ratios include  the errors due to:
* counting statistics,
* absolute abundance of the gamma lines,
* detector efficiencies,
* fission yields of the precursor
and the  least square analysis.
Research reactors CIRUS and APSARA of
Bhabha Atomic Research Centre, Trombay, Mumbai
neutron flux of 5x10**12 n/cm2/s using pneumatic
carrier facility of the reactor CIRUS
Irradiated solution or the
aluminum catcher foils were used for direct gamma
ray spectrometric assay of fission products or for
the radiochemical separation of tellurium, iodine
and cesium. On the other hand Lexan catcher foils were
washed with dilute nitric acid followed by distilled
water and used for direct gamma ray spectrometric
assay. The washing were carried out to avoid the
possible contamination of the activation product
238-Np* from the reaction 237-Np(n,alpha) and alpha
contamination of the actinide targets. Particularly
in the case of 243-Am, washing needed in avoiding
the constant gamma ray back ground of the daughter
239-Np, which is in equilibrium with 243-Am.
In the direct counting, the Lexan catcher instead of
aluminum catcher is preferred to avoid gamma ray
activities of the activation product 24Na from
27Al(n,alpha) reaction. The aluminum or Lexan catcher
or the radiochemically separated sample solutions were
counted on a 120 cm*3 HPGe detector.
For short-lived fission products nitrate solutions
of 237Np (~ 75 mu-g), 241Am (~ 50 mu-g) and 243Am
(~50 mu-g) were sealed in polypropylene tubes,
covered with 1 mm thick cadmium foil and sealed in
alkathene bags. For long lived fission products,
electrodeposited targets of 237Np (~150 mu-g),
241Am (~ 100 mu-g) and 243Am (~90 mu-g) were
covered with 25 mu-m thick aluminand sealed in
alkathene bags.
Approved by Dr.H.Naik, RCD, BARC
